Blog Copy 2023

December 19, 2022

Copy styling for general purpose blog entries in 2023. (Which is very likely to be used well beyond 2023.)

General Guidelines

These styles are intended for very general use between articles. They prioritize standard semantic HTML and simplicity. In most cases, styles are bound to single elements. However, this library also includes custom elements where applicable.

Below are samples of each style.

Light & Dark Modes

Both light and dark modes are supported, as well as utilizing the user's preferred color scheme.

If the user has a preferred color scheme activated, JavaScript will be used to apply the correct styling accordingly. This behavior can be overridden via a cookie.

In some cases, the lighting mode may need to be overridden manually. For example, if the content appears in front of an image which may be dark or light depending on the subject matter. This can be achieved by adding .bc23__color-scheme--light or .bc23__color-scheme--dark to the element in which the styling should apply, typically a node with a .layout-* class.

In all cases, be it user preference or manual override, an element's lighting mode is determined by the nearest .ambient--* class in the cascade.


Lighting Classes

.bc23__color-scheme--light

Forces the content within the element to render with "light" mode styling.

.bc23__color-scheme--dark

Forces the content within the element to render with "dark" mode styling.

Inline Snippets

Inline code snippets are as simple as wrapping text in a <code>code</code> tag.

Code Blocks

<code class="bc23__code-block">
<pre>
  console.log("Hello world!");
</pre>
</code>

  • The browser will honor the exact indentation of the <pre></pre> tag.

  • It's advised to use HTML entity codes when typing a code snippet. For example, the left and right arrow brackets in these docs use &lt; and &gt; respectively.

  • Since indentation and line breaks matter in various languages (apart for readability reasons), code snippets will scroll horizontally when their content overflows on the x axis.

    The scroll bars that appear on desktop browsers will be themed by the browser, usually based on its light/dark mode setting.

Code Snippets - Dark Mode

Inline example: console.log("Hello world!");. 


// code snippet
console.log("Hello World!");
